      <title>Breakthrough as scientists grow sheep embryos containing human cells</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/17/breakthrough-as-scientists-grow-sheep-embryos-containing-human-cells</link>
      <description><p>Advance brings us closer to growing transplant organs inside animals or being able to genetically tailor compatible organs, say researchers</p><p>Growing human organs inside other animals has taken another step away from science-fiction, with researchers announcing they have grown sheep embryos containing human cells.</p><p>Scientists say growing human organs inside animals could not only increase supply, but also offer the possibility of genetically tailoring the organs to be compatible with the immune system of the patient receiving them, by using the patient’s own cells in the procedure, removing the possibility of rejection.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/17/breakthrough-as-scientists-grow-sheep-embryos-containing-human-cells">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Earthlings likely to welcome alien life rather than panicking, study shows</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/earthlings-likely-to-welcome-alien-life-rather-than-panicking-study-shows</link>
      <description><p>Should aliens be discovered, public reaction is likely to be positive, say researchers – despite alarming fictional portrayals of contact</p><p>“The fear I felt was no rational fear, but a panic terror,” wrote HG Wells, describing his narrator’s response to a Martian invasion in War of the Worlds.</p><p>But despite such alarming portrayals, researchers say the discovery of alien life is more likely to be welcomed with open arms than panic.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/earthlings-likely-to-welcome-alien-life-rather-than-panicking-study-shows">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>George Church: "Genome sequencing is like the internet back in the late 1980s."</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/professor-george-church-nebula-genomics-interview</link>
      <description><p>The pioneering geneticist on why he wants us to earn money by sharing our genomic data, his plans to resurrect the woolly mammoth and how narcolepsy helps him generate ideas<br><br><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/genetics-how-do-you-make-money-from-your-dna">• How can I make money from my DNA? </a></p><p><strong>A new genetic testing company called </strong><a href="https://www.nebulagenomics.io/" title=""><strong>Nebula Genomics</strong></a><strong> wants to help people profit from their own genomes. The<em> Observer</em> talks to Harvard University DNA sequencing pioneer George Church about his latest venture, what’s cooking in his lab and how falling asleep on the job can sometimes be a godsend. </strong></p><p><strong>What is the value of getting your genome sequenced? Why do it?</strong><br>One very compelling argument that I think justifies almost everybody in the population getting sequenced is reproductive decision making: who to date, who to marry, whether or not to have gamete [egg/sperm] donors. Anybody that is of reproductive age, whether they intend to or not, are at risk of producing 5% of babies that are very severely affected with genetic disorders. Longer term, sequencing can enable the development of therapies that could provide years of enhanced quality of life.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/professor-george-church-nebula-genomics-interview">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How can I make money from my DNA?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/genetics-how-do-you-make-money-from-your-dna</link>
      <description>If you have your DNA sequenced, someone somewhere will be making money from the data. A new start-up aims to make sure that you get your share<br /><br /><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/professor-george-church-nebula-genomics-interview" title="">• A share in the future of DNA: Prof George Church Q&amp;A</a><p>If you unlock the secrets of your DNA by paying a company to read your genes, behind the scenes it is probably making money by selling on your data for research. Companies like <a href="https://www.23andme.com/en-gb/" title="">23andMe</a> and <a href="https://www.ancestry.co.uk/dna/" title="">AncestryDNA</a> charge consumers under £150 to learn about their health and/or origins, while others do whole genome sequencing for a little over £1,000 (although in the US it is cheaper at just under $1,000). The model works like this: send in a saliva sample, receive the results and provided you consent, which most people do because they want to help research efforts, the company retains control of the data. &nbsp;Pharmaceutical and biotech companies hoping to develop new drugs become their customers – off the&nbsp;back of your genetic information.</p><p><a href="https://www.nebulagenomics.io/" title="">Nebula Genomics</a>, a US based startup, wants to upend this exploitation. It will offer whole genome sequencing, but allow customers to keep custodianship of their data, which they can then rent to the drug companies they choose, potentially making a profit in the process.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/genetics-how-do-you-make-money-from-your-dna">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Stress in fathers may alter sperm and affect behaviour in offspring</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/stress-fathers-behaviour-offspring-altering-sperm-micrornas</link>
      <description><p>Research shows male mice exposed to a mildly stressful event produced sperm richer in certain types of molecules called microRNAs</p><p>Stressed fathers may end up with changes to their sperm that could affect behaviour in their offspring, research in mice has shown.</p><p>Previous work by the team found that male mice who were exposed to a mildly stressful event, such as being restrained, produced sperm that was richer in certain types of molecules called microRNAs. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/stress-fathers-behaviour-offspring-altering-sperm-micrornas">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Want to monitor air pollution? Test a pigeon</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/16/want-to-monitor-air-pollution-test-a-pigeon</link>
      <description><p>Feral pigeons are exposed to the same environmental factors as humans, so help explore the affect of contaminants, say researchers</p><p>Pigeons might be seen as the scourge of cities, but researchers say they could help us explore both the levels and impacts of a host of toxins in the air, from lead to pesticides.</p><p>Scientists say feral pigeons are a valuable way of probing contaminants in environment, since they are exposed to the same air, water, food and other factors as humans, and don’t venture far from home.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/16/want-to-monitor-air-pollution-test-a-pigeon">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Mindless eating: is there something rotten behind the research?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2018/feb/16/mindless-eating-brian-wansink-is-there-something-rotten-behind-the-research</link>
      <description><p>A storm of retractions, corrections, data irregularities and controversy over duplicate publication are destroying the credibility of Cornell’s Food and Brand Lab. It’s time for the university to be open about what’s going on<br></p><p>Most people probably haven’t heard of the beleaguered marketing professor, Brian Wansink, but chances are many will know about his work. Wansink is the mind behind the concept of “mindless eating” – the idea that the unconscious decisions we make about food can have profound effects on our diet and weight. Ideas like using smaller plates to eat fewer calories are pretty much engrained in our collective common sense, and stem from Wansink’s work over the past 20 years at the University of Illinois and now at Cornell University’s “Food and Brand Lab”. But for over a year, the veracity of Wansink’s research has been increasingly called into question, with five papers retracted (one of which was retracted twice), fourteen corrected, and <a href="http://www.timvanderzee.com/the-wansink-dossier-an-overview/">over fifty others facing scrutiny</a>.</p><p>The latest paper to fall under the spotlight is also one of Wansink’s most famous experiments. The <a href="https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/15761167">2005 paper</a>, titled Bottomless bowls: Why visual cues of portion size may influence intake, was a landmark study for Wansink. In it, participants were sat down at a table in groups of four, each in front of bowl of tomato soup. They were given twenty minutes to eat as much as they wanted, and then asked to rate, among other things, how much soup they thought they had actually eaten. The key manipulation was that while two of the participants had been sat in front of a normal soup bowl, the other two had bowls that could be covertly filled from the bottom. Wansink and his team claimed that although the participants given the self-refilling bowls ate about three quarters more soup, they didn’t believe that they had eaten any more than the other people around the table. This idea formed a core component of the well-known diet book Mindless Eating, and even won an Ig Nobel prize in 2007.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2018/feb/16/mindless-eating-brian-wansink-is-there-something-rotten-behind-the-research">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Friends, Romans, naked wolf-men ... why an ancient festival is still controversial</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/wolves-nudity-mayhem-why-an-ancient-roman-festival-is-still-controversial</link>
      <description><p>The annual Lupercalia festival turned society upside down – and the location of its starting point is still hotly debated</p><p>Scenes from films like Gladiator and series such as HBO’s Rome might lead you to think that the ancient Romans were liberal in their view of nudity. In fact the opposite was true. It was only during exceptional occasions that Romans were freed from their social norms – and the most spectacular occasion was the annual Lupercalia festival.<br></p><p>From the earliest days of Rome, 15 February was reserved for this strange festival. It was so unusual that Cicero disparaged the festival as savage and uncivilised remnants of primitive times. A closer look at the rituals might explain his attitude: men of the nobility stripped down to their underwear in order to strike women with strips of goatskin. Classed as priests, these were not men of the cloth as we would understand it – Roman religion was nothing like modern Christianity or Islam – but young men of military age who showed off their muscles running around the Palatine hill and the Forum, the city centre of ancient Rome.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/wolves-nudity-mayhem-why-an-ancient-roman-festival-is-still-controversial">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>What fossils reveal about the spider family tree is far from horrifying | Susannah Lydon</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/14/what-fossils-reveal-about-the-spider-family-tree-is-far-from-horrifying</link>
      <description><p>Recent fossils in amber tell us how spiders evolved into their modern groups, but the fossil record for arachnids goes much deeper</p><p>The discovery of a <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/05/very-creepy-crawlies-prehistoric-proto-spiders-with-long-tails-chimerarachne-yingi">100m-year-old spider ancestor with a whip-like tail</a>, bearing a more than slight resemblance to everyone’s favourite parasitoid alien – <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/film/2017/may/10/alien-covenant-ridley-scott-sequel">the facehugger</a> – gained a lot of media interest last week. Some arachnologists were upset by both the language of fear in the coverage (“creepy” and “horrifying” were popular descriptions) and by some folks expressing a desire to nuke it from orbit. It seems that despite (or perhaps because) of the intense responses that spiders evoke in people, there is always an interest in where and how they evolved.</p><p>The newly described species, <em>Chimerarachne yingi,</em> was based on two specimens found in amber of about 100 My old from Myanmar. Unusually, the new find was revealed in two simultaneously-published papers in the journal Nature Ecology &amp; Evolution. The rules for the naming of species mean that only one of the papers, by <a href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-017-0449-3">Bo Wang and colleagues</a>, gets to be the formal description and naming of the species (and new genus, the next level up in classifying organisms). Both Wang’s paper and that of <a draggable="true" href="https://www.nature.com/articles/s41559-018-0475-9">Diying Huang and colleagues</a>, aimed to place the new find in terms of the spider family tree. The new species has features of modern spiders, known as the Araneae: a male pedipalp (sensory appendage) modified for sperm transfer, and well-defined spinnerets for silk spinning. But, it also has its distinctive tail, a feature not found in modern spiders, but associated with an ancient grouping of “almost-spiders” known as the Uraraneida.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/14/what-fossils-reveal-about-the-spider-family-tree-is-far-from-horrifying">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Why it's too soon to classify gaming addiction as a mental disorder</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2018/feb/14/gaming-addiction-as-a-mental-disorder-its-premature-to-pathologise-players</link>
      <description><p>Concerns over the addictive properties of video games are reasonable but there is a lack of rigorous research behind the WHO’s expected classification</p><p>Video games played on smartphones, tablets, computers and consoles have been a popular form of leisure for some time now. In Europe, <a href="http://www.isfe.eu/sites/isfe.eu/files/gametrack_european_summary_data_2016_q4.pdf">recent figures indicate</a> that games are played by more than two thirds of children and adolescents, and a substantial number of adults now play games – 38% in the UK, 64% in France, 56% in Germany and 44% in Spain.<br></p><p>The WHO will publish the next revision of its manual – the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-11) – by mid-2018 and gaming disorder has been <a href="http://www.who.int/features/qa/gaming-disorder/en/">included in the draft</a> for the first time.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/head-quarters/2018/feb/14/gaming-addiction-as-a-mental-disorder-its-premature-to-pathologise-players">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Hot stuff: the thermal cameras giving us a new way of seeing our bodies</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2018/feb/14/hot-stuff-the-thermal-cameras-giving-us-a-new-way-of-seeing-our-bodies</link>
      <description><p>How do our bodies regulate themselves – and is it even true that we have a single body temperature? New technology will tell us</p><p>I’m one of those people who always feels cold. Maybe it’s my upbringing in the chilly north, or maybe it’s down the quirks of my own physiology, but I’m reliably found next to the fire, hiding from draughts that no-one else had noticed, or buried inside enough jumpers to stock a small shop. At the other end of the scale, when everyone else is sweating buckets, I’m basking smugly because I’m finally at a comfortable temperature.</p><p>Like most of us, my attitude towards my body temperature is similar to Goldilocks’ attitude to porridge – it’s either too cold, too hot, or 37C, which is just right. But I’ve rarely considered the fascinating details of exactly how our bodies regulate their temperature, and whether it’s even true that we have a single body temperature anyway. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/blog/2018/feb/14/hot-stuff-the-thermal-cameras-giving-us-a-new-way-of-seeing-our-bodies">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Crack and cheese: do things really affect your brain 'like drugs'?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2018/feb/13/crack-and-cheese-do-pleasurable-things-really-affect-your-brain-like-drugs</link>
      <description><p>Claims that cheese, sex and Facebook affect your brain in the same way as drugs fundamentally misunderstand how it all works</p><p>The internet is a weird place. Part of this is due to how things linger rather than disappear, as they tended to do with more “traditional” media. Nowadays, people’s jobs can (rightly or wrongly) be endangered for <a href="https://hellobeautiful.com/2930429/affinity-magazine-old-tweets/">tweets they wrote</a> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2015/mar/31/trevor-noah-backlash-highlights-jokes-jews-women">years ago</a>. The adage about “today’s news is tomorrow’s fish and chip papers” seems no longer to apply. </p><p>This is particularly true when a headline or story from years ago can be found by a group or community on a social network that missed it previously, so they share it widely and it ends up in your feeds long after it’s been “forgotten”. It can be a bit confusing for those of us who grew up solely with televised news. It’s like watching the weekend football roundup when it’s suddenly interrupted by a report that the Berlin Wall has come down. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/brain-flapping/2018/feb/13/crack-and-cheese-do-pleasurable-things-really-affect-your-brain-like-drugs">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Non-invasive imaging reveals landscape painting beneath Pablo Picasso’s The Crouching Beggar but who created it remains a mystery</p><p>Wrapped in a mustard coloured blanket with a white scarf and her head on one side, Pablo Picasso’s <em>La Misereuse Accroupie</em> (The Crouching Beggar) is a study of forlorn resignation.       <title>A child's gender can be detected in their speech from age five, research says</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/child-gender-speech-age-five-research-university-minnesota</link>
      <description><p>University of Minnesota academics say boys and girls pick up speech cues from adults around them, resulting in differences</p><p>The gender of children can be picked up from their speech from as young as five years old, researchers have revealed.</p><p>While male and female children have no physiological reason for sounding different before puberty, when changes to the larynx kick in, researchers say boys and girls pick up telltale speech cues from adults around them, resulting in perceptible differences in their speech. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/16/child-gender-speech-age-five-research-university-minnesota">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ammonia emissions rise in UK, as other air pollutant levels fall</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/15/ammonia-emissions-rise-air-pollutants-fall-new-government-statistics</link>
      <description><p>Levels of powerful air pollutant rose by 3.2% from 2015 to 2016 according to government statistics</p><p>Emissions of ammonia have been on the rise in the UK, new statistics from the government show, even while the amount of other pollutants entering the atmosphere has fallen.</p><p>Levels of the powerful air pollutant rose by 3.2% from 2015 to 2016, the latest year for which statistics are available, according to a report published by the Department for the Environment, Food and Rural Affairs on Thursday morning. The rise came despite an overall fall of 10% in ammonia emissions since 1980.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2018/feb/15/ammonia-emissions-rise-air-pollutants-fall-new-government-statistics">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>DIY faecal transplants carry risks including HIV and hepatitis, warn experts</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/diy-faecal-transplants-carry-risks-including-hiv-and-hepatitis-warn-experts</link>
      <description><p>Faecal transplants have been used in medical settings to tackle superbugs, but following YouTube videos at home is too risky, say researchers</p><p>Concerns have been raised about the growing trend for DIY faecal transplants, with experts fearing such attempts could put individuals at an increased risk of HIV and hepatitis as well as conditions ranging from Parkinson’s and multiple sclerosis to obesity and sleep disorders.</p><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2013/mar/31/bacteria-faecal-transplant-gut-mary-roach-gulp">transfer of faeces from one human to another</a> has gained attention as a growing number of studies have suggested links between microbes in the gut and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2016/aug/01/is-your-gut-making-you-sick">a host of health problems</a>, from autoimmune diseases to anxiety.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/diy-faecal-transplants-carry-risks-including-hiv-and-hepatitis-warn-experts">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/blood-thinning-drugs-designed-to-cut-stroke-risk-may-actually-increase-it</link>
      <description><p>Scientists call for caution in prescribing anticoagulants after some patients with other conditions found to suffer more strokes</p><p>Blood-thinning drugs may increase rather than cut the risk of stroke in some people over 65 who have an irregular heartbeat and also chronic kidney disease, according to a new study.</p><p>The researchers are calling on doctors to be more cautious in prescribing the drugs, called anticoagulants, until there has been more research. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/15/blood-thinning-drugs-designed-to-cut-stroke-risk-may-actually-increase-it">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>The next level of driverless cars: how to solve the problem of humans falling asleep</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/next-level-driverless-cars-how-to-solve-the-problem-of-humans-falling-asleep</link>
      <description><p>Next wave of development will see drivers only expected to intervene when the car requests it, say researchers</p><p>Driving down the motorway in a swanky semi-autonomous car, the vehicle is at its own wheel, humming along smoothly. But coming off a slip road it is over to you. The only trouble is, you’ve fallen asleep. </p><p>The goal of a completely driverless car is considered top of <a draggable="true" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_car#Levels_of_driving_automation">a six-level scale of autonomy</a>, and researchers believe it will one day be possible to achieve that aim. But for now, cars are stuck at level two on the scale – in which the driver must still perform several key aspects of driving – while engineers work out how to crack the problem of keeping drivers alert. <br tabindex="-1"></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/15/next-level-driverless-cars-how-to-solve-the-problem-of-humans-falling-asleep">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>China’s great leap forward in science</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/china-great-leap-forward-science-research-innovation-investment-5g-genetics-quantum-internet</link>
      <description>Chinese investment is paying off with serious advances in biotech, computing and space. Are they edging ahead of the west?<p>I first met Xiaogang Peng in the summer of 1992 at Jilin University in Changchun, in the remote north-east of China, where he was a postgraduate student in the department of chemistry. He told me that his dream was to get a place at a top American lab. Now, Xiaogang was evidently smart and hard-working – but so, as far as I could see, were most Chinese science students. I wished him well, but couldn’t help thinking he’d set himself a massive challenge.</p><p>Fast forward four years to when, as an editor at <em>Nature</em>, I publish a paper on nanotechnology from world-leading chemists at the University of California at Berkeley. Among them was Xiaogang. That 1996 paper now appears in a 10-volume compendium of the all-time best of <em>Nature</em> papers being published in translation in China.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/18/china-great-leap-forward-science-research-innovation-investment-5g-genetics-quantum-internet">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Trump's moon shot might be steered by a woman, says Nasa chief</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/17/trump-moon-mission-woman-nasa-astronaut</link>
      <description><p>A third of America’s astronauts are women, says Dr Ellen Ochoa, a director at an agency that has come a long way on equality</p><p>There is at least a one in three chance that the first human to set foot on the moon this century will be a woman, Dr Ellen Ochoa, the head of Nasa’s Johnson space center has said.</p><p>In the early 1960s Nasa sent out rejection letters saying it had no plans to send women into space. Among those who apparently received the brush-off was a <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/fact-checker/wp/2015/11/30/hillary-clintons-often-told-story-that-nasa-rejected-her-childhood-dream-of-becoming-a-female-astronaut/?utm_term=.20339c52da61">teenage Hillary Clinton</a>. But the agency has since changed its tune, and in 1983 Sally Ride became the first American woman in space. In 2013 Nasa announced that <a href="https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2013/06/half-nasas-new-class-astronauts-are-women/314165/">half of its new class of eight astronauts were women</a> – a first for the agency.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/17/trump-moon-mission-woman-nasa-astronaut">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>E-cigarettes and the burning issues around vaping - Science Weekly podcast</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2018/feb/16/e-cigarettes-and-the-burning-issues-around-vaping-science-weekly-podcast</link>
      <description><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/profile/iansample">Ian Sample</a> asks: how safe is vaping? Can it help people stop smoking? And should it be available via a doctor’s prescription?</p><p><strong>Subscribe and review on <a href="https://itunes.apple.com/gb/podcast/science-weekly/id136697669?mt=2">Apple Podcasts</a>, <a href="https://soundcloud.com/guardianscienceweekly">Soundcloud</a>, <a href="https://audioboom.com/channel/guardian-science">Audioboom</a>, <a href="https://www.mixcloud.com/guardianscience/">Mixcloud</a> and <a href="https://www.acast.com/guardian-science">Acast</a>, and join the discussion on <a href="https://www.facebook.com/GuardianPodcasts/">Facebook</a> and <a href="https://twitter.com/guardianaudio">Twitter</a></strong></p><p>If you’re not a smoker, it may be hard to imagine the appeal of cigarettes. The idea of inhaling thousands of chemicals into your body just doesn’t seem that tempting. It’s hard to wrap your head around the addiction if you haven’t experienced it and even more difficult to appreciate how hard it is to quit. But according to a <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/news/phe-publishes-independent-expert-e-cigarettes-evidence-review">new report</a> released by Public Health England (PHE) <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/06/vaping-is-safe-way-to-quit-smoking-says-health-body">electronic cigarettes are significantly safer than smoking</a> and can offer a potential aid for smoking cessation. But how much do we really know about vaping and its risks? Is there consensus between scientists and the public? And should the NHS be encouraging the use of e-cigarettes to aid quitters?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/audio/2018/feb/16/e-cigarettes-and-the-burning-issues-around-vaping-science-weekly-podcast">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Weatherwatch: Extreme flooding on rise in Europe over past 20 years</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/12/weatherwatch-extreme-flooding-on-rise-in-europe-over-past-20-years</link>
      <description><p>Scientists track global statistics and conclude past events are not reliable predictors for future risk</p><p>For the inhabitants of the Cumbrian village of Glenridding, the winter of 2015/16 was a miserable one. Storm Desmond brought the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/07/chaos-cumbria-floods-lake-district-turn-lives-upside-down">first deluge</a> in December, turning the river into a raging torrent, sweeping through many properties, and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/nov/27/glenridding-cumbria-storm-desmond-floods-hotel">cutting the village off from the outside world</a> for a full two days. <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/dec/25/christmas-day-flood-warnings-prompt-meeting-of-emergency-cobra-committee">Storm Eva</a> barrelled in a few weeks later, and Glenridding ended up awash three times in the space of four weeks.</p><p>So what is going on? Are extreme climate events becoming more frequent, or were the residents of Glenridding suffering a series of unlucky rolls of the dice?</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/12/weatherwatch-extreme-flooding-on-rise-in-europe-over-past-20-years">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Starwatch: in Orion's sword is the hazy blob where stars are born</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/11/starwatch-in-orions-sword-is-the-hazy-blob-where-stars-are-born</link>
      <description><p>The hunter stands bolt upright in the evening sky, with the nebula visible below the belt</p><p>This week is a good one for finding the constellation of Orion: it stands bolt upright in the evening sky. The chart shows the view looking due south at 20:00 GMT on 12 February. The most noticeable thing to look for is Orion’s belt comprising three stars: <a href="https://www.astronomytrek.com/star-facts-alnitak/">Alnitak</a>, <a href="http://www.astronomytrek.com/star-facts-alnilam/">Alnilam</a> and <a href="https://www.astronomytrek.com/star-facts-mintaka/">Mintaka</a>. Look upwards from the belt and you find the red giant star <a href="https://www.space.com/22009-betelgeuse.html">Betelgeuse</a> (famously pronounced beetle-juice). It marks one of Orion’s shoulders and is conspicuously red in colour. About as far below the belt is the bright blue-white star Rigel. The real prize, however, hangs just below the belt. Three fainter stars make up Orion’s sword. The lower one, Hatysa, is the brightest but look closely at the middle “star” and you will see it is not a star at all but a hazy pink blob. It is the star-forming region known as the <a href="https://www.nasa.gov/feature/goddard/2017/messier-42-the-orion-nebula">Orion nebula</a>, which houses thousands of nascent stars. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/11/starwatch-in-orions-sword-is-the-hazy-blob-where-stars-are-born">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Steven Pinker: ‘The way to deal with pollution is not to rail against consumption’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/11/steven-pinker-enlightenment-now-interview-inequality-consumption-environment</link>
      <description><p>The feather-ruffling Harvard psychologist’s new book, a defence of Enlightenment values, may be his most controversial yet<br><br><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/books/2018/feb/11/reason-is-non-negotioable-steven-pinker-enlightenment-now-extract">• Read an extract from Enlightenment Now here</a></p><p>Say the word “enlightenment” and it tends to conjure images of a certain kind of new-age spiritual “self-improvement”: meditation, candles, chakra lines. Add the definite article and a capital letter and the Enlightenment becomes something quite different: dead white men in wigs.</p><p>For many people, particularly in the west, reaching a state of mindful nirvana probably seems more relevant to their wellbeing than the writings of, say, Immanuel Kant and Adam Smith. But according to <a href="https://www.guardianbookshop.com/enlightenment-now-549057.html" title=""><em>Enlightenment Now</em></a>, a new book by the celebrated Harvard cognitive psychologist <a href="https://stevenpinker.com/" title="">Steven Pinker</a>, this is precisely where we’re getting our priorities wrong.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/11/steven-pinker-enlightenment-now-interview-inequality-consumption-environment">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description>Rocket Lab entrepreneur Peter Beck’s recent launch into orbit of Humanity Star drew a barrage of flak. But he remains undaunted<p>Last month, from its base in New Zealand, Peter Beck’s space company, Rocket Lab, conducted its first successful attempt to put satellites in orbit. The launch vehicle, the Electron, carried a payload including the Humanity Star, a very shiny, 65-sided, carbon-fibre satellite whose only function is to reflect the sunlight as it spins. Scientists didn’t approve: astronomers claimed it would interfere with their observations, others called it “space graffiti”, while the <em>Scientific American </em>described it as “satellite vermin”.</p><p><strong>Space X</strong></p><p></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/11/one-mans-mission-to-conquer-space-peter-beck-humanity-star">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Is the answer that we have run out of good questions? | Kenan Malik</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-the-answer-that-we-have-run-out-of-good-questions</link>
      <description><p>We are supposed to be inquisitive and yet …</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2012/jan/08/john-brockman-edge-interview-john-naughton">John Brockman</a> has run out of questions. Brockman, a literary agent, runs the science and philosophy site <a href="https://www.edge.org/">Edge.org</a>. Every year for 20 years, he has asked <a href="https://www.edge.org/people">leading thinkers</a> to answer a particular question, such as: “What questions have disappeared?” or: “What do you believe is true even though you cannot prove it?” This year, though, Brockman announced that he has no more questions left. So he asked his final question: “What is the last question?”</p><p>“Judge a man by his questions rather than by his answers,” Voltaire insisted. Questions help us define what we don’t know and force us or others to justify what we think we do know.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/is-the-answer-that-we-have-run-out-of-good-questions">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How long can we treat the suffering of animals as an inconvenient truth? | Michael Brooks</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/how-long-treat-pain-of-animals-inconvenient-truth</link>
      <description>A revolution is coming in our relationship with ‘lower’ creatures, provoked by a greater knowledge of their cognition. Labour’s new plans for animal welfare are just a start<p>Scientific insight is a powerful thing, but will it ever override the human lust for health, prosperity and, saddest of all, convenience? This question entered my head as I read of the Labour party’s newly announced <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/14/animal-welfare-labour-policies" title="">policies for animal welfare</a> “informed and underpinned by the latest evidence on animal sentience”. Such an approach would lead to laudable b<a href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/feb/14/foie-gras-and-badger-culling-would-be-banned-under-labour-proposals" title="">ans on foie gras imports and nonsensical badger culling</a>. But let’s be careful what we wish for: further down the line, it would also lead to some uncomfortable dilemmas. In fact, how we redraw our relationship with animals promises to be one of the dominant themes of the coming decades.</p><p>Those alert to animal sentience already find themselves in difficult situations. Richard Dawkins, for example, has declared: “We have no general reason to think that non-human animals feel pain less acutely than we do.” This, Dawkins says, should change our cultural habits. Practices such as branding cattle, castration without anaesthetic and bullfighting, for instance, “should be treated as morally equivalent to doing the same thing to human beings”.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/how-long-treat-pain-of-animals-inconvenient-truth">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The media exaggerates negative news. This distortion has consequences | Steven Pinker</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/steven-pinker-media-negative-news</link>
      <description><p>Whether or not the world really is getting worse, the nature of news will make us think that it is</p><p>Every day the news is filled with stories about war, terrorism, crime, pollution, inequality, drug abuse and oppression. And it’s not just the headlines we’re talking about; it’s the op-eds and long-form stories as well. Magazine covers warn us of coming anarchies, plagues, epidemics, collapses, and so many “crises” (farm, health, retirement, welfare, energy, deficit) that copywriters have had to escalate to the redundant “serious crisis.” </p><p>Whether or not the world really is getting worse, the nature of news will interact with the nature of cognition to make us think that it is. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/17/steven-pinker-media-negative-news">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Performance-driven culture is ruining science | Anonymous Academic</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/2018/feb/16/performance-driven-culture-is-ruining-scientific-research</link>
      <description><p>I was told impact metrics could make or break careers. Instead, they broke my faith in scientific research</p><p>The first time I heard about the impact factor I was a few weeks into my PhD. A candidate due to finish in a couple of months warned me emphatically: “It makes or breaks careers.” In my innocence, I didn’t think much about it and returned to concentrating on my research. A decade later, metrics such as these came to dominate my work and ultimately drove me to give up my permanent academic post and move into industry. <br tabindex="-1"><br tabindex="-1">Since leaving academia, I have found myself wondering about the effect of these metrics on the profession and practice of science.</p><p> <span>Related: </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/2017/jun/30/pressure-to-publish-in-journals-drives-too-much-cookie-cutter-research">Pressure to publish in journals drives too much cookie-cutter research</a> </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/higher-education-network/2018/feb/16/performance-driven-culture-is-ruining-scientific-research">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Does the Illuminati control the world? Maybe it’s not such a mad idea | Julian Baggini</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/14/illuminati-running-world-not-mad-idea-questioning-hidden-power-elites-sane</link>
      <description><p>Questioning the hidden power of elites – whether big pharma or secret societies – is really quite sane</p><p>If <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/nov/22/what-is-illuminati-google-autocomplete" title="">the Illuminati</a> is real, it’s got to be the <a href="http://www.bbc.com/travel/story/20171127-the-birthplace-of-the-illuminati" title="">least secret secret society</a> in the universe. It’s so bad at keeping itself hidden that its existence is proclaimed all over the internet by people whose investigative toolkit consists entirely of Google and a lively imagination.</p><p>The most recent would-be whistleblower, however, is far from your usual <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/David_Icke" title="">ex-sports commentator</a>. Paul Hellyer, a former Canadian minister of defence, has blamed the Illuminati for <a href="http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-5384051/Fmr-Canadian-minister-says-Illuminati-controls-world.html" title="">suppressing technology brought to Earth by aliens</a> that could end our reliance on fossil fuels.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/14/illuminati-running-world-not-mad-idea-questioning-hidden-power-elites-sane">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>How dangerous is Jordan B Peterson, the rightwing professor who 'hit a hornets' nest'?</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/how-dangerous-is-jordan-b-peterson-the-rightwing-professor-who-hit-a-hornets-nest</link>
      <description><p>Since his confrontation with Cathy Newman, the Canadian academic’s book has become a bestseller. But his arguments are riddled with ‘pseudo-facts’ and conspiracy theories</p><p>The Canadian psychology professor and culture warrior Jordan B Peterson could not have hoped for better publicity than <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aMcjxSThD54">his recent encounter with Cathy Newman on Channel 4 News</a>. The more Newman inaccurately paraphrased his beliefs and betrayed her irritation, the better Peterson came across. The whole performance, which has since been viewed more than 6m times on YouTube and was described by excitable Fox News host Tucker Carlson as “one of the great interviews of all time”, bolstered Peterson’s preferred image as the coolly rational man of science facing down the hysteria of political correctness. As he told Newman in his distinctive, constricted voice, which he has compared to that of Kermit the Frog: “I choose my words very, very carefully.”</p><p>The confrontation has worked wonders for Peterson. His new book 12 Rules for Life: An Antidote to Chaos has become a runaway bestseller in the UK, US, Canada, Australia, Germany and France, making him the public intellectual du jour. Peterson is not just another troll, narcissist or blowhard whose arguments are fatally compromised by bad faith, petulance, intellectual laziness and blatant bigotry. It is harder to argue with someone who believes what he says and knows what he is talking about – or at least conveys that impression. No wonder every scourge of political correctness, from the Spectator to InfoWars, is aflutter over the 55-year-old professor who appears to bring heavyweight intellectual armature to standard complaints about “social-justice warriors” and “snowflakes”. They think he could be the culture war’s Weapon X.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/how-dangerous-is-jordan-b-peterson-the-rightwing-professor-who-hit-a-hornets-nest">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>I’ll say it again: E-cigarettes are still far safer than smoking</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/sifting-the-evidence/2017/jan/02/ill-say-it-again-e-cigarettes-are-still-far-safer-than-smoking</link>
      <description><p>Despite evidence suggesting e-cigarettes are far less harmful than smoking, more people than ever believe them to be just as harmful. Professor Linda Bauld discusses the evidence</p><p>January is a time for New Year’s resolutions and if you’re one of the world’s one billion smokers, your resolution may be to stop smoking. For some people, this year’s quit attempt might involve an electronic cigarette, and a <a href="http://www.bmj.com/content/354/bmj.i4645">recent study</a> in England, published in the BMJ, suggested that these devices helped at least 18,000 smokers to stop in 2015 who would not otherwise have done so. That’s very good news, but will there be as many quit attempts in 2017 as there have been in the past with e-cigarettes? I’m not so sure. </p><p>Since I last wrote about e-cigarettes <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/sifting-the-evidence/2015/dec/31/no-theres-still-no-evidence-e-cigarettes-are-as-harmful-as-smoking">in this column</a> one year ago, <a href="https://www.thesun.co.uk/living/1693653/e-cigs-are-just-as-bad-for-your-heart-as-smoking-fags-as-they-damage-key-blood-vessels-say-experts/">headlines</a> about the dangers of these devices have continued to appear and show no sign of abating. The result is clear. More people believe today, compared with a year ago, that e-cigarettes are as harmful as smoking. In fact these <a href="http://ash.org.uk/information-and-resources/fact-sheets/use-of-electronic-cigarettes-vapourisers-among-adults-in-great-britain/">incorrect perceptions</a> have risen year on year, from fewer than one in ten adults in Great Britain in 2013 to one in four this past summer. Surveys of smokers show similar patterns, with an increasing proportion believing that e-cigarettes are more or equally harmful than tobacco. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/sifting-the-evidence/2017/jan/02/ill-say-it-again-e-cigarettes-are-still-far-safer-than-smoking">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>First modern Britons had 'dark to black' skin, Cheddar Man DNA analysis reveals</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/first-modern-britons-dark-black-skin-cheddar-man-dna-analysis-reveals</link>
      <description><p>The genome of Cheddar Man, who lived 10,000 years ago, suggests that he had blue eyes, dark skin and dark curly hair</p><p>The first modern Britons, who lived about 10,000 years ago, had “dark to black” skin, a groundbreaking DNA analysis of Britain’s oldest complete skeleton has revealed.</p><p>The fossil, known as Cheddar Man, was <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2011/feb/16/cheddar-cave-skull-cups">unearthed more than a century ago in Gough’s Cave in Somerset</a>. Intense speculation has built up around Cheddar Man’s origins and appearance because he lived shortly after the first settlers crossed from continental Europe to Britain at the end of the last ice age. People of white British ancestry alive today are descendants of this population.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/first-modern-britons-dark-black-skin-cheddar-man-dna-analysis-reveals">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Ultra-processed foods may be linked to cancer, says study</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/14/ultra-processed-foods-may-be-linked-to-cancer-says-study</link>
      <description><p>Findings suggest increased consumption of ultra-processed foods tied to rise in cancers, but scientists say more research is needed</p><p>“Ultra-processed” foods, made in factories with ingredients unknown to the domestic kitchen, may be linked to cancer, according to a large and groundbreaking study.</p><p>Ultra-processed foods include pot noodles, shelf-stable ready meals, cakes and confectionery which contain long lists of additives, preservatives, flavourings and colourings – as well as often high levels of sugar, fat and salt. They now account for half of all the food bought by families eating at home in the UK, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/02/ultra-processed-products-now-half-of-all-uk-family-food-purchases">as the Guardian recently revealed.</a></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/14/ultra-processed-foods-may-be-linked-to-cancer-says-study">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/cutting-asparagus-could-prevent-spread-of-breast-cancer-study-shows</link>
      <description><p>Using drugs or diet to reduce levels of asparagine may benefit patients, say researchers</p><p>Breast cancer patients could be encouraged to cut asparagus and other foods from their diets in the future to reduce the risk of the disease spreading, scientists say.</p><p>Researchers are investigating whether a change in diet could help patients with breast tumours after studies in mice showed that asparagine, a compound first identified in asparagus but present in many other foods, drives the spread of the disease to other organs.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/cutting-asparagus-could-prevent-spread-of-breast-cancer-study-shows">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>SpaceX oddity: how Elon Musk sent a car towards Mars</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/space-oddity-elon-musk-spacex-car-mars-falcon-heavy</link>
      <description><p> A Starman sitting in a tin can is currently navigating the heavens, soundtracked by David Bowie. How did it – and we – get there?</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/video/2018/feb/06/falcon-heavy-worlds-most-powerful-rocket-successfully-launches-video">Video: watch the launch of the Falcon Heavy rocket</a><br></li></ul><p>It takes a beat or two for the brain to compute. The image is startling, incongruous, barmy. A car floats in space. At the wheel is a spacesuit, seatbelt on. Earth hangs behind it. The two objects don’t work together. The image jars like bad Photoshop. But it is real. </p><p>The photograph was beamed down to Earth courtesy of Elon Musk’s ego, bravado and taste for the absurd. It is human folly and genius rolled into one, a picture that sums up 2018 so far. Life on Earth feels precarious, so we look to the stars.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2018/feb/07/space-oddity-elon-musk-spacex-car-mars-falcon-heavy">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/jul/23/what-i-learned-from-home-dna-test-kits-are-they-accurate-or-worthwhile</link>
      <description>They promise to reveal everything from our ancestry to our chances of serious illness. But are DNA tests accurate and do they tell us anything worthwhile?<p>There may come a time in everyone’s life when they find themselves sitting at the kitchen table on an otherwise unexceptional weekday morning, drooling saliva into a test tube in the spirit of scientific inquiry.</p><p>The spit is for one of the home genetic-testing kits I’m sampling. A growing number of these kits (brands such as 23andMe, DNAFit, Thriva, MyHeritage DNA, and Orig3n) promise to unlock the mystery of your genomes, variously explaining everything from ancestry, residual Neanderthal variants, “bioinformatics” for fitness, weight loss and skincare, to more random genetic predispositions, denoting, say, the dimensions of your earlobes or the consistency of your&nbsp;earwax.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/jul/23/what-i-learned-from-home-dna-test-kits-are-they-accurate-or-worthwhile">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>China’s moon mission to boldly go a step further</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/dec/31/china-mission-to-far-side-of-the-moon-space-discovery</link>
      <description><p>China may achieve a feat never attempted by the US or USSR – landing on the far side of the moon</p><p>This time next year, there may be a new world leader in lunar exploration. If all goes according to plan, China will have done something no other space-faring superpower has been able to do: land on the far side of the moon. China is rocketing ahead with its plans for lunar exploration. In 2018, they will launch a pair of missions known collectively as Chang’e 4. It is the fourth mission in a series named after the Chinese moon goddess.</p><p>The first component of Chang’e 4 is scheduled to lift off in June. It will be a relay satellite stationed some 60,000km behind the moon and will provide a communications link between Earth and the lunar far side. Once this link is established, it will allow China to send the second part of the mission: a lander to the far side’s surface.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/science/2017/dec/31/china-mission-to-far-side-of-the-moon-space-discovery">Continue reading...</a></description>
